comments.commentBody:
Trump listens to Manafort who listens to Putin. Why else question obligations under the NATO treaties?

Manafort says Trump's political message emulates that of Nixon, but this is only a dodge to avert attention from the Putin influence (after years of Manafort being on the payroll of Putin's Ukranian puppet and other dictators).

How many Russian oligarchs have economic interests intertwined with Trump. Perhaps we'll never know, but a good start would be to examine his tax returns --- the ones he'll never show!!!

Wake up Aurora!

Citizens of all political tribes (or no political tribe) are invited to vote for Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine in November.  Do you dare to stay home or vote for a third or fourth party team?  You need not love the Democratic ticket. You need only to love your country and understand that either Mrs. Clinton or Mr. Trump will be sworn in next January.  Patriots of all stripes, please step up.

While I am a bit concerned that Mrs. Clinton is a bit more "hawkish" than I would like, I am more concerned about Mr. Trump's willingness to abandon commitments to our NATO partners given the aggressive policies of Mr. Putin. One has to wonder if Mr. Trump has cut another one of his famous deals again, this time a Faustian deal in which his campaign receives Russian money for his Presidential campaign in exchange for our abandoning our NATO allies Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia if he were to become President.  Far-fetched? Not by the rules that Mr. Trump plays by.

What exactly is Mr. Trump's relationship with Russia?  Is it true that he has significant business relations and credit lines from Russian sources?  Is his apparent accommodationist attitude toward Mr. Putin based on personal business interests?  Did he arrange for the Republican Platform to eliminate support for an independent Ukraine?  Do Mr. Trump's tax documents hold some of the answers to these questions?  Is there a sinister pattern to Mr. Trump's persistent deceptions?  Republicans and Democrats alike need answers.
It's time for all serious and responsible Americans to reject this Trump madness and vote for the Democratic Party - up and down the ballot. The GOP is morally bankrupt.

Excuse me?

The Chinese use basically slave labor to build the products that fill our Walmart’s and Target’s (and every other store, look at the labels at Saks).  If you go to the factories in Shenzhen they have suicide nets under the dormitories, twelve people to a room, making our sleek and beautiful iPhones.  Pollution controls are unheard of, toxic stuff dumped in their rivers and our air. 

In addition, they have a predatorily priced currency.  This combination provides for a price point that Western manufacturers simply cannot match, since they are required to provide not only 20 times the wage but health care and retirement. For our citizens, so they can lead a middle class life. 

As a result, our and Europe's manufacturing bases have been devastated.  

Why is this somehow OK?  Why is this practice enshrined in a 'trade deal' thought of as sacrosanct?  Have you been to small town or mid-sized town American and seen the devastation, as if by war?  Have you seen the formerly employed people now adrift embracing meth and heroin?  Have you been to the inner cities where young men don't have any chance whatsoever of ever being employed by the manufacturers long since departed?

Ivory tower, indeed, Editorial Board.

"It is unclear, even now, whether he is listening to anyone."

The RNC convention showed us who he listens too: his children Ivanka and Donald Jr as well as his son in law. These are seasoned veterans not in national and international affairs but in dealing with their impetuos, self-aggrandizing and ADD father.
I don't think we have anything to worry about with regard to Trump. His bromance with Putin and Russian money has put Trump right where he wants to be - in Putin's pocket.
Night and day comes to mind and finding something positive in this mess would help too.

I'm in general agreement on facing the world, as you state, but what about consumers' protection with the World of Banks, and revelations about Tim Kaine's bank regs record in supporting less consumer protection vis - a- vis banks?

What if you needed a neurosurgeon to remove a tumor from your brain. One said, "I have been doing this for many years as the Chairwoman of Neurosurgery of this hospital, I read voraciously and publish about the subject, and I am willing to work with other experts to do the best for you". The other said, "I have never done this, but I am very smart, believe me. I don't need to read, get advice, or have any experience. I will just get my daughter to hold the retractors (look great in blue scrubs, doesn't she?), blast the sucker out of there, build a wall around the hole, and you will be great again."
If you choose the later, maybe you need to go see a neurosurgeon?

" an increasingly aggressive Russia "

This increasingly aggressive Russia is entirely the creation of the US. You managed to get rid of Yanukovych that Moscow was comfortable with, and proceeded to immediately recognize the subsequent, unelected government In Kiev. You insisted "Assad must go" knowing full well that he was Russia's ally.

Are you people insane? I really do not want to wake up one morning and see a mushroom shaped cloud outside my window.

Russia's aggressiveness is in your MIND. America's aggressiveness is a fact on the ground.

If Trump does not want to mess around with a nuclear power, he is wise.

Trump's exact words about foreign policy advisers (I'm not making these up):

"I listen to myself. I've got a good brain, I say a lot of things."

Sarah Palin with testosterone, no more no less.

We are now at that point we arrive at every four years when these pages return, as punctually as a lunar eclipse, to their election-year role as the daily newsletter of the DNC.  It doesn't matter that the candidate of choice this year plays at being a liberal but is the golden girl of Wall Street, and it doesn't matter that Wikileaks showed that her rival, a man of integrity was indeed sabotaged by her friends in party leadership, and it doesn't matter that she betrayed national secrets and has the authenticity and likability of a real estate agent who just sold you a house you cannot afford.  She's the one.  FYI: I don't like the other folks' choice all that much either.  But, please, stop carrying on like this is a battle of good against evil.  It is a fight of dishonesty against dishonesty, right down the line.  It is a national embarrassment.

What is Trump's fascination with Putin due to?  Could it be business dealings that he has had or wants to have for himself? How can the military turn over our national secrets to a guy who admires Putin?

Actually, it seems that the 2 are more alike than different. Both oppose free trade agreements, which is terrible economics. Hilary is probably closer to the current administration than you suggest and, like trump, will not intervene militarily in the Middle East. The NATO comment from Trump is just bloviation and yet both want our NATO allies to do more.

On international relations and global economics, the 2 are not that far apart -- and both spell trouble for America.

Time for the NYT Editorial Board to catch up with the Washington  Post, whose brilliant editorial proclaimed Trump "a clear and present danger to Democracy". That speech on Thursday reeked of nationalism and fascism:do we really want his brain to guide our nation in foreign policy or domestic policy or even selecting new curtains for the East Room? We readers expect courage and truth from "The Paper of Record" and we are waiting for that editorial.

There is a proverb in my native country which goes like this 'show me your friends or admirers and I will show you your character'. Let us apply this native rule of my country of origin to The Trump. Among his admirers are President Nixon, Putin and Mussolini.

America wake up. We need not lay the red carpet for the demagogue.

'Cry for the beloved country' matching inexorably to the cliff hypnotized by The Trump. America needs not be hypnotized and victimized votary of The Trump.

Trump is bad on so many levels.  Possibly abandoning NATO is absurd.  And he basically says, "Trust me.  Everything will be terrific soon after I'm elected."  But he gives NO details on how he's going to accomplish this miraculous result.
We do not want Donald Trump anywhere near the red button. And we do not want Donald Trump recklessly goading some despot into launching missiles against the USA.  He is a loose cannon!

As the editorial states, " Mrs. Clinton’s long record makes it easier to predict how she views America’s role in the world." Certainly true.

The predictors range from her barely admitted " mistake" in Iraq, to her disaster in Libya, to her approval of the coup in the Ukraine, to her continuing provocations of Russia and to her uncritical support of an Israel that steals land and kills civilians with impunity. There are also her family friends and advisors like her "mentor" Henry Kissinger, her "friend" Hosni Mubarek and all those dictators and despots around the world who have so lavishly funded her Clinton Foundation while applying for arms sales from the US.

Yes Hillary's record as Secretary of State shows we can easily predict that Hillary will bring to the Presidency - endless war.

Great choice and reflective of Secretary Clinton's well known strengths in governing outside of an election cycle filled with heated rhetoric.

Republican former Indiana Gov. Mitch Daniels: “She is comprehensively experienced and has advantages that some of the other contenders would have to scramble to match in terms of her exposure to the world and… foreign policy.”

Republican former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee described Sec. Clinton as “smart," "tough” and "a policy genius."

Former Utah Gov. John Huntsman said "I’ve worked around Hillary Clinton while serving as ambassador to China and all I can tell you is she’s smart. She’s hardworking. She relates to all kinds of people, and I was very, very impressed working with her as a Republican."

Republican Ohio Gov. John Kasich: “I like Hillary.” He turned down the offer to serve as Trump's VP, attend the GOP convention in his own state, or even endorse him for President.

Republican Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said, "I think (Clinton's) efforts in trying to reform the nation’s health care system are most commendable."

Republican Rep. of New York Peter King said, "It is hard for me to imagine Hillary Clinton ever being sick. She’s one of the strongest people I’ve ever met in my life."

Former General David Petraeus said, "(Hillary Clinton) would make a tremendous President."

The truth is Secretary Clinton is the most qualified candidate for President in generations running against the least qualified.
Trump is documented as having NO attention span -- he is clearly NOT up to the challnge of addressing pressing issues on all fronts simultaneously:  national or international.

Trump has obviously been taking money from Putin. Trump will not let anyone see his tax returns -- guess why not? Putin and Russia have been funding right wing movements in Europe, including the Brexit vote, according to Professor Timothy Snyder of Yale. Professor and columnist Paul Krugman raised the question about Putin funding Trump in his most recent NY Times column.

Trump has literally sold out America.

Go to YouTube watch Comedy Party Platform (2 min 9 sec). Send a buck to Bernie and Elizabeth (Warren), invite me to speak, save America. Thanks. wkb321@gmail.com
It is hard to have a clear vision of where you want to lead the country when you don't even have a clear vision of what the facts are.
